title: Realizing an RDF-based Information Model for a Manufacturing Company – A Case Study

author: Niklas Petersen, Department of Enterprise Information Systems (EIS), University of Bonn

segmentation: So yeah, my name is Peter Peterson.
I present the paper realizing an RDF based information model.
You can hear me.
Well, yes for a manufacturing company, so report on a project where we applied semantic technologies and foreign enterprise and industrial domain.

What was the motivation the company wanted to establish data driven applications manufacturing in their factory sites and they did this as a first step by attaching to everything they could to production lines of machines sensors.
But they they had an massive growth of data.
However, they weren't yet really able to use it in their daily decision making, so the sensors weren't really well described where they're attached to at what they're looking at.
And they wanted to make more use out of it and to automatize more and more production lines using those sensors.
They also had a lot of tested knowledge and the brains of the experts.
Of the workers in the factory, which was not digital in anyway, and they would like to make it more explicit to make it also available outside of the factory to other factory sites.
So maybe certain expert knowledge is shared among the entire company.

And so overall they wanted to have a bigger picture of the entire production in their company, and that's why we, yeah, that's why they wanted to develop an information model which grows over the machines.
But action lines, the databases and etc.
So.

So we didn't want to just create an information model which you can print output on the wall, or have some nice PowerPoint presentations about now we define two very concrete use cases where we wanted to use it.
One is 2 management, so they have the picture on the right is a.
Machine tool yeah machine which is used to shape metal and to refine it, and they had actually very low quantities of products they developed here so highly specialized metals.
Yeah, for different things and it wasn't running for four weeks or days, but it was reconfigured this machine every few hours in.

This reconfiguration time was very slow and the tools they plugged into it into the machine brought very had to exchange separated, broke down and then they had to stop the production and reconfigure the machine and where the tools are within the factory was also something which sometimes costs time delays because certain things were not available or were at a.
Place where the worker didn't know where to get it so they they didn't have any kind of formalization, how?
The machines can be configured and they didn't take this into consideration in their production plans.
Because if they had something like this or there was a plan they could.
Take this into account and maybe they have to reconfigure the machines less often because there are similar orders which have similar configurations.
And the second use case we had was energy consumptions.
So even if it sounds very trivial an they weren't yet able to calculate the energy costs of single work orders, they will only be able to calculate them for the entire site.

So they wanted to go down to the factory to different buildings, different machines and different work orders to know exactly how expensive the energy costs are to adapt the pricing, but also to maybe move certain productions.
Into the night where the energy electricity costs are lower.
How did we create that information model?
Yeah, we used that.
We showed methodology which defines some very basic steps in 1995 which are still true today and adapted a little bit for ourselves.
So we defined the purpose scope, captured the domain knowledge, conceptualize it, and at the end aligned to existing ontologies.
So what is an information model for us?
It's a formal description of all the physical assets of the different sides of the machines of the production lines.
It's, uh, it includes the mappings to the relational databases to structural data which is already available.
And also some formalized domain related knowledge as I described before the tool to configure them where they are, which tool maybe breakdown can breakdown very quickly, etc.
How far do we want to go?
How granular should the information model become so we stop in that moment where we can address the use cases to solve those problems?
Of course, it's an ongoing thing which the company extends and extends, but for now the goal was to address the use cases.
How did we capture the domain knowledge?
We got a lot of input material massive.
Associate's PowerPoint presentation where certain things were explained.
Of course data dumps.
We had a non factory visit where the workers explained out how they work.
What are the problems, what they would like with the information model to be solved in the future.
We had multiple workshops and their different shareholders.
Factory managers.
The machine worker.
The factory manager the.
I teach computer scientists, Department heads and.
Yeah, the database administrators were involved.
And we reviewed all the accessing property model standards.
Tool to use and we organize our information model using Revoker.
It's basically.
At the bottom.
Yeah, good version control system so we keep track of the changes.
Also information model and at the front end we have different views on a web interface to look in a tabular fashion on classes, instances to query the information model to edit it etc.
So this web interface helped our domain experts to view it without having to install anything like Portage for example and proteges of course.
Also very heavy.
Not so easy.
To use.
And at the end we use existing standards industry standards and.
Align them to our information border.
So how does it look?
Like so, the central concept is our machine tool which we saw in the picture before the machine tool is of course a machine.
There are other machines like a drilling press, record machine, etc.
From the machine tool we described that there are certain work orders which have to be.
Executed on it at certain dates.
It requires certain machine operators which have the skill to produce these things.
To configure it, we need certain material.
We need the tools configured into the machine, so this is not everything, but it gives you a high level perspective from the machine tool.
Anne.
Yeah, so the machine tool is part of a production line which has multiple working cells which is a section within the Hall.
The hardest part of a plant.
And the whole list.

Of course the building and the plant has other facilities on the sides and at the end it's attached to the enterprise which has multiple brands and all the locations of everything but hazard you location like machines or how it's described to it.
And yeah, everything was Gray is something we edit ourselves to it because we couldn't find any ontology describing these things.
Otherwise we use Neo Geo to describe the geographical things, locations and ramian.
I see standards.
Yeah, to describe the production lines.
The tool ontology we.
Also, to develop entirely, yeah by ourselves since I didn't access anything.
What you see on the left is the interface of the machine, so there are different kind of interfaces.
Change magazines, disk magazines to revolver.
They have different kind of adaptations which they called tool store basic Holder.
There are different ways recorder, single, double or triple Holder, and there's another adaptation.

The reason why there are so many adaptation is because they are across different vendors involved and everyone has a different configuration set and at the end when you have added those adaptation, you finally have the tool itself.
For example, a drill and milling cutter.
Etc.
How did we employ it into there?
IT infrastructure so of course we would build up on the existing relational databases they had.
It was out of scope to create to transform the relational data into triples, and it was not something they wanted to do.
So we created wrappers around the relational databases on the right side the Postgre SQL was the sensor database.
They have a bill of material manufacturing, execution systems and.
On the right left was all the data we had to formalize ourselves because it wasn't anywhere formalized about the tools and typical configurations.
All that these mappings to the relational databases and everything which we had to formalize ourselves we put together in the information model and made it available by different applications.
To solve the use cases.
So for the tool management, we created a geographical perspective which was received very well.
So finally they had something where they could grasp the information model.
It's not something yes.
I said you put on the wall, but you can actually interact with it.
So on the world map you can zoom into different factory sites.
You see the outline of the building of the factory.
And they are the different machines are can be interacted with, so by by clicking on different.
Here on the rectangle you got some information about the machine tool which order is currently executed, what kind of configuration does it have?
Which is the next order?
Where are the tools for the next order, etc.
So the machine operator could easily find them and track them down.
And.
Exactly and the different storage site which were pattern Masters and the factory where is located what currently?
The second app was the energy consumption app based on the sensor data to calculate for each hour.
How how much energy I was consumed?
For different orders for different production lines or for the Hall itself?
And yeah, we were not allowed to show also the data in the relational databases.
But we also added Sparkle endpoints to different relational databases to explore different work orders.
That was in the interest of the user.
So what are they?
Lessons learned by working with the company.
In general, they were very enthusiastic to develop an information model with us.
There were, as I said, multiple stakeholders involved.
Some of them preferred in the beginning to 1st internally sum everything up and create a internal view before they go outside.
But from the management perspective they did this all the time and they didn't get forward, so they were really interested in getting an external viewer on all their assets.
So.
They there was a lot of skepticism among especially computer scientists, righty heads, about the maturity of the semantic technologies.
There was always a question.
Who else is actually using it?
Of course it would be perfect if Tesla uses it, because then we could sell it better.
So it was a big part of our negotiation at the beginning to point to successful projects and to explain them exactly how it would be used.
How would be the return of investment, etc.
A.
Another experience was so as a result of the project they want to build up.
They're on, yeah.
Enterprise architecture Department and using semantic technologies.
However, it was quite difficult for them to hire semantic web professionals which have an industrial experience and apply these things in within their region so.
Which then maybe also be explained that most universities offer usually database an Excel courses, but semantic web is not a standard.
Um, yeah, governance of the information model was also a major topic with them so.
Who's allowed?
Which are the roads was allowed to edit when or which part?
How to modernize?
Maybe the information model?
So that's something which was.
Of major importance to discuss that together with the enterprise.
And as I said before, they had no interest in throwing away their existing infrastructure.
But to build on the top of it.
So we did.

Form different strategies how there could be realized using replication of data to not interfere with the production systems which shouldn't be slowed down by any access from outside or to use dams if it's possible.
Or maybe to have a live access.
So what is the?
Vision can be observed that there are.
Yeah, multiple organizations emerged in the last year which tried to integrate and production systems together.
In France and discreet, if you tour in the US, Industrial Internet and Germany, industrial data space or in general it's called industrial industry for the 0.
Ann is a very hot topics, however most of them don't take the semantic aspect into account to describe everything, and this is something our community really should do and.

Some problems we observed are that I mean, of course all this industry consortiums, which trade standards they usually they have no interest in creating ontologies and put them out into the web because it's a business model to sell those and.
That's something which maybe need to change.
One discussion with that that on top select Sparkle one on one support.
There's a tool.
Lack of full support for RML which we are using.
And yeah, currently we are guiding the enterprise and building our high level Ontology which describes also fuzzy processes etc.
That's it.
Thank you, thank you.
Seems to me you tackle the age old gap of the bridge between domain expert in data expert right?
Yeah, my question goes towards scalability in terms of rollout manufacturing is a highly heterogeneous domain a tooling machine is radically different from a solder joint printing machine.
Whatever you can be organized in lines in Pools, Workshop organization, they seem to be workshop.
So my question is like how do you judge the investor had to take if I move this around the different areas of manufacturing?
Or in other words, how much do I have to do to?
Put your tool support your visual front end onto a different domain in manufacturing.

The front end I would say it's based on Neo Geo, so every kind of things I don't know if you have different kind of production lines and you describe them with a geographical ontology, it's quite easy.
So the visual view would work out of the box.
About describing different domains, I think that's a very very long topic, so we just started there are.
I was sometimes called told in the steel domain there exist hundreds of different standards how to?
Yeah, to produce it.
OK, I like the German word, but yeah, there are multiple ones and that's just nearly no ontologies at all.
So it would be a very long and expensive process of course.
Thank you on this is calling from on top team.
Just a comment.
Not really question on this lacking or sparkle impossible and support.
We are working hard on it so.
Yeah, yeah we can contact later so I'm just saying that we are working very hard on all these features.
It will be there.
OK yeah sure yeah.
So in addition to the enthusiasm can you quantify actually addition to what?
In addition to the enthusiasm of the manufacturing company, and so can you quantify what was the actual value that bringing these semantic technologies brought?
Because the problems that they are describing you can solve it by doing a warehouse.
I mean, there's people been solving those problems always, right?
So what was the value quantified, please?
I think it's a greater picture, so they introduced multiple sensors.
They have their existing IT infrastructure and they were.
It was very hard for them to have a bigger view on all the data assets about the things within the what's really happening in the factory, which is not formalized already.
So I would say the biggest value of the information model was to create this bigger view.

So it was explorable by them to find which databases which data about which machine or probably you have a specific examples of data integration or entity recognition that because you use ontologies and semantic web technologies you could you could solve and if you just use relational model you couldn't.
I mean, you could quantify it by the reduced time of the machine worker because he's faster or they they don't have to configure the machines alone anymore, but unfortunately don't have exact hours.
Do they have with Pacific examples where you could say that, for example, sense to you entology you were able to integrate or do entity recognition?
I mean yeah or also about the energy consumption, so they adapted.
The work orders are for different products.
To make them more real to the real energy costs and but I unfortunately don't have any data on how much they saved by moving them to the night shifts.
Yeah, we don't have any other question.
Many thank you, thank you.
